pros: Good learning environment, with great attendings
cons: Parking is expensive, but conveniently located next to a metro station

pros: They basically bribe you with good pay for horrible working conditions
cons: Cut throat, incompetence, condescending directors who think they built the place, you advance based on who you know

pros: Staff was amazing and caring for patients. Great place to learn and train. Leadership could be a little more communicative.
cons: Could see some complacency but that just meant employees were comfortable

pros: To be honest I do not have any good things to say about GW
cons: To be honest one management here sucks. Each day a new staff of onboarded and we barely kept that one

pros: Fellow staff are very friendly and helpful to new employees Hybrid work (primarily remote)
cons: Health benefits are terrible and expensive High employee turnover, so you often have to work multiple jobs to help cover when employees leave Pay increases are rare, and somewhat low for the D.C. region Equipment isn't provided to work from home (other than a company laptop)

pros: Leaving at the end of the day!
cons: Pay, benefits, management, 401k, parking, leadership and money management is just terrible at this organization.

pros: Pay is decent, The only thing thats keeps us going is the people you work with. The company is metro accessible.This is a good place for newbies, if you are looking for a foot into healthcare MFA is a good start.
cons: Organization has no structure, management turn over is crazy. Health insurance is not the best. No employee parking.

pros: There are really no pros to this company it’s a horrible company.
cons: Company as a whole have a very high turnover rate lack of communication and direction. Leadership is horrible.

pros: Great clinical team Always learning Past-paced
cons: Disorganized Low pay No promotions

pros: Kind and wonderful people who care about their patients
cons: Under financial stress for several years

pros: During my time here, there were a lot of changes in management and the technical infrastructure. These changes provided a lot of opportunities for advancement within the company.
cons: Unfortunately, the same changes mentioned as a Pro is also a Con because there was a lot of instability in leadership and work. For example, the project you spent the last six months working on could be immediately discarded for a new initiative from new management.

pros: Cool staff, sometimes challenging work
cons: Working overtime on salary pay meh

review_title: Overall good company to work for

review_title: One of the worst places to work for.
pros: Flexibility… they don’t care, that’s the fact!!!! Providers are good even though they are not supported enough. There are few very hard working people.
cons: If you are looking for structure this is not the place to work. If you’re a hard working person, please stay away. Oh corporate politics is huge at the MFA! Favoritism, nepotism..it’s about who you know. HR is the worst, from recruiting to benefits administrators….Just stay away from this place for your own sanity. Partnership with NThrive is a complete failure. NThrive staff , I don’t even want to start … Benefits are subpar; paid parking; antique technology…. There is a long list.

pros: There is none. I just want to spend a couple of years with the MFA and leave.
cons: So many to list here

pros: There were literally none. And I mean none
cons: Favoritism, Poor Conflict Resolution Skills, Prejudice

pros: Love my co-workers and my actual job
cons: Low pay with no raises, overworked

pros: Great docs and medical care
cons: No option for staff to telework

pros: I have the most positive coworkers.
cons: Have been there for 2 years and never received a cost of living wage.

Tech culture based on aggressive vs passive aggressive communication style
Tech culture unprofessional and uses favoritism for scheduling duties and clinics and no accountability from upper management

pros: The tuition reimbursement and pay. The people are friendly. Punch in, is through finger print so you can be sure that you paid accordingly. The location is really convenient too, right in the heart of the city. Quick response to IT problems.
cons:
There isn't much work to do and no one directs new employees or train them properly. When there isn't work you just have to sit there and wait until there is work to do. This is at the business office. The bathrooms are keyed so no more than 2 people can go to the bathroom.  Training is done by other current employees. Strict managment (no personal calls, emails ect.)! There are rats in the facility, so beware of food and make sure to clean your desk every morning (in case of rats). There are no windows either.

If you pass out, no one will help you even though it's a physician health practice. They have to call the police and get you on an ambulance. Which is ridiculously because there are at least 100 doctors in the building.

You will never know how you are doing because there isn't a feedback system in place. No performance review. So you could be let go without noticed.

pros: Company is restructuring so it is going through a transformation
cons: Company restructuring and there are layoffs so staff morale is low

pros: Job security-- with so many physicians leaving, they can't afford to release anyone
cons:
The physician leadership structure is seriously flawed. There are physician leaders  in divisions of 5-10 people who do little clinical work, so as a physician, you are working to support the outsized salaries of these leaders. 5-10 self driven people don't need that amount of management at that cost; it ultimately leads to non-competitive salaries for the front-line physicians. 
Leadership has been awarded by politics and favoritism, and not merit. Leaders use their position for self-betterment rather than advancement of the organization's goals.
There is no accountability for leadership. There is an understanding that advancement is by political maneuvering, and not merit, so many good people have left or are looking to leave.

pros: You have a job be happy
cons: Too many to tell but no raises in 2 years.

review_title: If you are looking for a career with potential for growth this is not the place.
job_title: Certified Medical Coder in Washington, DC
pros: Friendly and helpful co workers
cons: There's no room for growth. They don't invest in continued education. Upper Management decides your faith without knowing what it takes to make things work. A lot of long hours with no compensation for some. No one is treated equal. The health insurance is unaffordable.  You a basically forced to receive all your healthcare needs here and there's no security in place which means everyone knows all your business and believe me they share it. Some of the Physician are very disrespectful but because they are considered God management does nothing. They constantly say they have no financial means for raises, better benefits etc for the administrative staff but are constantly adding COO, CEO, CIO etc position while the people doing all the work are barely making it.  A lot of the employees find themselves applying for state medical because they cannot afford the benefits the offer. I wonder why the offices on the 10th floor are enclosed like a fortress and when all those big money people get on the elevator with the other employees they turn their noses up like the smell something. I ve there 4 years with no raise and now they are saying still no raises but they keep giving these employee reviews telling you to do more really. Yes time to move on!!!!

pros: Too little to make mention of
cons: Too many to list here

pros: Good place to get exposure to academic medicine
cons: High turnover for physicians, poor benefits compared to peers

pros:
Great physicians and medical faculty
Conveniently located near Metro and large variety of restaurants and eateries
Access to urgent care
cons:
Extremely poor management and operations; chaotic; hostile, fearful work environment
Many complaints of retribution/retaliation for filing HR complaints or reporting harassment (sexual, verbal)
Poor leadership
Very shady and unethical business practices
Physicians have little to no say in scheduling, operations, work space, clinic layout
Decisions made secretly and without input of medical faculty
Elitist attitude towards employees/patients/contractors
Poor treatment of employees and patients (from service perspective)
Employees treated like children
Blacklisted if you question inconsistencies in policies or practices
Shady HR management
Poor to non-existent benefits
Low salaries; Annual increases very minimal despite large margins year after year (you'll  always hear "well its a recession" or "healthcare is not doing well", " we'll re-evaluate your pay in 6 months" and it never happens.  But the practice continues to open new offices and buy smaller groups)
No break rooms or lunch areas
Medical records of physicians and employees are snooped
Emails snooped

pros: It is one of the most influential healthcare organizations in the nations capital.  The benefits are decent.
cons: There is no room for growth.  The company has experienced a lot of turnover in the C-Suite and the future is uncertain.  The company is currently going through a transition.  The company makes you use PTO if you cannot make it to work because of the snow.  The organization also has a practice of putting/keeping individuals in leadership roles who do not have the competence that such roles require.  A lot of this is due to political relationships.

pros: I've worked on a lot of different projects. Haven't been limited to just end user training. I've enjoyed meeting and training all kinds of roles in all specialities. Really like most of my coworkers. Company offered Epic certification and trips to annual user group conferences. Great holiday party. :)
cons: 1. Pattern of failing to promote from within causes us to lose a lot of good people. People want to move up after a while, and with nowhere to go inhouse they quit. 2. Lack of clear, consistent direction from upper management. We seem to have a lot of different objectives, and they change depending on who you're talking to. At the moment, there doesn't seem to be anyone in charge.

pros: The organization seems to be interested in changing for the better.  There is operational efforts to make enterprise wide changes that will leverage the size of the organization.  The complete change in leadership gives the organization opportunity to remake itself rather than accepting what was done in the past as "gospel".
cons: There is a huge disparity in the treatment of providers v staff; this is changing as the bottom line and consistent business operations becomes more important.  As the ones who bring in the revenue there will always be the divide between providers, and staff, but treating all employees equitably is becoming more of a focus.

job_title: Registered Medical Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: The 2150 Pennsylvania location is very convenient to Foggy Bottom Metro!
cons:
Poor management, inadequate and poor training, too many cliques and favoritism amongst management and staff, management and leaders are disrespectful towards staff, and it's basically a very unorganized and dysfunctional organization that doesn't appreciate nor embrace the quality and years of  expertise that's employees bring to this organization!

 Instead, your character is defamed by lies, and you're humiliated and disrespected by those who are intimidated by the knowledge and skills that you bring to the MFA, because they fear you surpassing them someday!!

review_title: Team work , compassion, going the extra mile, customer service, respect, confidentiality are terms MFA/AMG missed in cla
pros: Best part of working at MFA was meeting/helping patients and being appreciated for taking the time to listen and helpful by the patient.
cons: Coworkers wanting to be seen as "I'm the only one working, see me working hard, no one else work hard as me, I can do everything and multitask "

pros: Location and access to GW University, the culture of the company is focused on making money, but each department can be different - with some focusing on work life balance.
cons: Staff morale, management, salary/benefits; generally the bulk of the people that work here are overworked, underpaid, and generally unhappy (or incompetent). Management is focused on profits at the expense of the people; there is a lot of staff turn over

job_title: Tier II Engineer in Washington, DC
pros:
- No micro management 
- Very easy work
cons:
- No real process structure
- No real growth opportunities 
- Finger pointing culture

job_title: Medicine/Call Center Call Center Senior Patient Service Specialist in Suitland, MD
pros: Working with some of the staff and the daily task of assisting the patients and doctors.
cons: employees are not compensated for their hard work and I do not believe that certain staff are treated as valuable.

pros: The pay as good but the benefits not so much. I was making almost $20.00 an hour. And the patients are so sweet.
cons: Small space to accommodate everyone. You have students, staff and patients and sometimes it can become over crowded. There is also no where to park got employees, if so it’s extremely expensive. Metro is your best bet.  One more thing be aware of some of the ghetto employees who don’t know you and try to start mess with you.

pros: I learned a lot while working at MFA. The people you work with are very friendly and they help you in your career especially some of the docs
cons: There are a few down sides, one being that the scheduleing varies widely depending on which office you work with. Sometimes the patients you deal with will feel entitled depending on the area.

pros: Management is okay, the doctors are great to work with.
cons: There is no room for growth. The company only pays a 3rd of your tuition which would you could only attend GW University. Your raise is set before your evaluation which is no point to do an evaluation if that's the case.

pros: Really isn't much to say that's good about this company. I haven't been pleased for a long time. It is in a great location
cons: Benefits aren't good. You can only see Mfa Drs for your medical care plus pay $20. If you go outside its $60 copay. There is a lot of drama and upper management is unstable. Some of the Drs are very rude and don't greet you. They will have you handling 2 or 3 job functions because they are short staffed. And if your manager doesn't want you to leave they will blackball you until you quit.

review_title: The job was okay. PAs are not used to their full advantage.
pros: Experience, proximity to food and metro, academic opportunities, team environment, grand rounds sometimes interesting. Interdisciplinary opportunities are available if you look for them.
cons: No room for growth, not challenging, management doesn’t care about PAs. I had an incident here, tried to advocate, and nothing was addressed. It was clear no one cared.

pros: Excellent faculty to work with, especially with the international resident training program.
cons: Department head is clueless as to the ability of some supervisors and managers to lead and/or manage.  It is hard to manage when you are on Facebook and/or logged into a chat room "all" day. Employees are not given an opportunity to be promoted within the department - - positions are filled without employees being told an available position exist within.

pros: I loved working with great co-workers, helping patients and encountering learning experiences every day. My manager was great and promoted professional growth even if it was outside of the GW MFA.
cons: The benefits package could be better and there's and lack of trust with higher-ups (which could be said for most companies). A couple of pending lawsuits from former staff doesn't help, either.

job_title: Emergency Medicine Residency Program Coordinator in Arlington, VA
pros: Affiliation with GW medical school and hospital.  Great location in DC.
cons: Mismanagement of finances, human resources, faculty/staff career and professional development, disorganization, expansions to too many offices and not enough staff support, near bankruptcy, little concern for staff wellness, facade, patient care is not the #1 priority and money is in the forefront.  Faculty are glorified while staff are underappreciated.  Too much red tape and politics.  Malignant environment...

review_title: RUN AS FAST AS YOU CAN!!!! DO NOT ACCEPT THE OFFER!!!!
job_title: Billing Customer Service Representative in Arlington, VA
pros: The only reason I feel like I stayed at this hell hole company was because of the pay. The interview process is extremely easy with this company.  You are bribed to become an employee with MFA by the salary they offer you. You basically ask for $5 an hour, and they offer you $10. It is the only good thing about this company. The benefits are pretty good as well, but that didn't take place until this year.
cons:
Where do I begin...?
This was the worst company I have ever worked for in my entire life. NO money for essential supplies your employees need to get their job done, NO money for raises, NO money to fix broken equipment, NO money for nothing. It's sad when you are rationed out supplies at your JOB; 10 paper clips, 12 staples, and 2 rubber bands because the company has no money for supplies. The printer would break every week in this department, and to this day they have not ordered a new one. Their IT department is more lost than the employees who have never fixed a computer a day in their life... The customer service billing department is the worst department to work for!!!!! Just imagine a bunch of older catty women whispering, gossiping about one another, and complaining about the job all day long (35-75 years old). IT IS AN EXTREMELY SAD AND MISERABLE PLACE TO BE. It was such a toxic work environment to be a part of. They hire employees in this department who have not a clue of how to even read an EOB, including management!!!!! Family members and friends are being hired within the same department, criminals due to HR not running background checks,  just about anybody can work for MFA. I'm not so sure how the other departments were ran, but from what I heard they were ratchet and drama filled too. EXTREMELY GHETTO, Filthy bathrooms, childish women (35 and up), drama, no structure, and no consistency. I don't wish for anyone to lose their jobs, but I do not see this company running for more than another 2 years if things do not change. FAST. God bless MFA.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
pros: Lots of opportunities for learning and career growth. Great people, great location.
cons: Everything works completely differently in each department. There is no standardization across the board and leadership often places a focus more on pointing fingers and placing blame rather that resolving issues.

review_title: Not Really a Good Place to Work
job_title: Patient Account Team Lead in Arlington, VA
pros: Able to get as much overtime you want *in certain departments*. Flex time available *in certain departments*....That's about it.
cons: Poor management structure. Politics and bureaucracy keep any issues from getting resolved. Employees generally have a bad attitude. Morale is low. Benefits are not great & company may stop contributing to your 401k anytime they please. This business lacks organization on every level.

pros: You get to work with excellent physicians who still care about their patients.
cons: Internally this organization is so disorganized. Senior management fights among themselves to play the blame game. And HR is the puppet of all PGAs. You are on your own!

review_title: Metro Immediate and Primary Care - GW MFA
pros:
Coworkers and some providers. They are the only reason I could manage to go to that horrid place at all. Was sad when I had to leave them. I want to go back to visit them but the thought of going back gives me serious PTSD.
Tuition benefits if you can afford go there.
Working 3 days a week and sometimes 4 days off but so tired you can't do anything.
Close to the metro but the thought of working there will make you cry all the way there and want to miss your stop and just keep going.
cons:
Where do I even begin? First, DO NOT WORK HERE. If you're looking for a sign, this is it.
- Favoritism from previous management. Won't go into it because it makes me gag.
- The best MAs have left, no one to train the new ones bc the person who is supposed to sits in the office and twiddles on the phone.
- Getting one 15 minute break per 13 HOUR shift, ONLY if you ask for it. Don't ask, don't eat.
- Being unable to drink water when working the front desk because no one (including the office lead) will cover you for 2 minutes.
- Working 2 weekend days/month in addition to already working three 13 hour shifts
- Taking patients until literally 30 seconds before closing time. Providers will assess and prescribe in 5 minutes and go home immediately, MAs are stuck there until much later to clean up and process labs. All while upper management works a 9-5 with a solid lunch break.
- Management will not care when certain providers treat you like crap from time to time and take our their personal frustrations on you.
- Give you a grocery store gift card for thanksgiving then tax you for it.
- Management will discourage and block you from going to HR if you have a problem with them or someone they like. 
- No room for growth.
- MA's complain, write emails, have meetings day after day and no change.
- Little pay. If you have kids don't even bother. The college grads here are fine with it because they don't know better. You will have to beg, scream, fight and cry for a review even after multiple years only to be told they can give you a 25 cent raise. A quarter. 2 dimes and one nickel.
- No coverage. They are chronically understaffed and over booked with appointments so if someone calls out, no one wants to cover and you'll be stuck there by yourself with multiple people barking orders at you and running like a chicken with its head cut off. Bring advil.
- Providers also hate being there and openly talk about quitting. I've literally seen one type out a 2-weeks notice right at their desk. Once I left, I was invited to brunch by some providers who previously quit to congratulate me on "getting out".

pros: The MFA is undergoing a dramatic overhaul.  There are lots of opportunities for those that work hard enough to be noticed.  It's an exciting time if you enjoy taking part in the change.
cons: There is a lot to be done, and the pacer is demanding.

pros: Large organization with multiple locations, specialists etc...pay is ok..easy access to communicate within the company..CEO etc ..the company is continuously growing
cons: Some of the community practices acquired by the MFA are set in their ways & behind on times the employees end up at a disadvantage

pros: Nice place to work,diverse patients. The physicians are young and old. Close to metro for transportation
cons: As a teaching facility they only offer tuition assistance for GWU at 2/3 %. Raises are at 2% or less, management is clueless of the loads of work. micromanagement in thee wrong areas

pros:
Work/life balance
Commute
A few go-getters who want to help improve the organization
cons:
CEO and senior management lacks a clear focus
No overarching strategic direction 
Wasteful with resources
Infighting and politics among physicians/senior management
Big egos, small brains

job_title: Patient Service Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: My co-workers and supervisor was awesome. Great team work. Provides lunches sometimes. My manager helped, took up for us.
cons: Not to much room for growth. They make hard to transfer to any other department for new a position. Especially if your current department in doing a great job or even short staffed. Better salaries.

pros: A new CEO, hopefully he will revamp and no longer tolerate the extreme nepotism.

pros: Great people and a wonderful team atmosphere among close colleagues. Many opportunities to advance due to high turn over.

review_title: Company lacks patient and employee empathy!
